etymology.description: 电 ‘electricity’ + 话 ‘speech/words’ = electric speech → telephone/phone call.
etymology.interpretation: A modern Sino-Japanese coinage (電話, denwa) adopted into Chinese, literally ‘electric speech’. Highlights speech transmitted via electricity; in use it can mean both the device and a call.
etymology.simplification: Both characters were simplified in PRC reforms to reduce strokes and speed writing: 電 → 电 by compressing the lightning/rain elements; 話 → 话 by reducing 言 to 讠 and streamlining the right-side component.

examples.chinese: 他给我打电话(他給我打電話)。
请接一下电话(請接一下電話)。
我忘了带手机，只能用办公室的电话(我忘了帶手機，只能用辦公室的電話)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ wàng le dài shǒujī, zhǐnéng yòng bàngōngshì de diànhuà.
examples.english: I forgot my cell phone, so I can only use the office phone.
